revision.text:
{{redirect|Jabby|another person nicknamed "Jabby"|Gérard Crombac}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{good article}} {{Infobox military person |name= James Jabara |image= JamesJabaraPortrait1940s.jpg |image_size= 200 |alt= |caption= (c.1950s) |nickname= "Jabby", "The Ceegar Kid" |birth_date= {{Birth date|1923|10|10|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]] |death_date= {{Death date and age|1966|11|17|1923|10|10|df=yes}} |death_place= [[Delray Beach, Florida]] |placeofburial= [[Arlington National Cemetery]] |allegiance=United States of America |branch= [[United States Army Air Forces]]
[[United States Air Force]] |serviceyears= 1943–1966 |rank= [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] |unit= |commands= [[31st Tactical Fighter Wing]]
[[337th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]] |battles= [[World War II]]
[[Korean War]]
[[Vietnam War]] |awards= [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Army Distinguished Service Cross]] (2)
[[Silver Star]] (2)
[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] (7)
[[Air Medal]] (24)
[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|British Distinguished Flying Cross]] |relations= |laterwork= }} '''James "Jabby" Jabara''' (10 October 1923 – 17 November 1966) was the first American and [[United States Air Force]] [[flying ace|jet ace]] in history.{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International|United Press]]|title=Jet Ace Out of Combat|work=[[The New York Times]], ''22 May 1951 (Fee required)''|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E16FF39591A7B93C0AB178ED85F458585F9|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=22 May 1951}} Born in Oklahoma, he lived in Kansas where he enlisted as an aviation cadet at [[Fort Riley]] after graduating from high school. Jabara attended four flying schools in Texas before he received his pilot's wings and was commissioned as a second lieutenant. Jabara flew two tours of combat duty in Europe during [[World War II]] as a [[North American P-51 Mustang]] pilot, and scored 1.5 air victories against German aircraft. Jabara flew his first jet aircraft in 1948, the USAF [[Lockheed F-80 Shooting Star]] before transitioning to the USAF [[North American F-86 Sabre]]. Jabara used this aircraft to shoot down multiple Soviet-built [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]] jets during the [[Korean War]]. He achieved his first confirmed air victory of the war on 3 April 1951. A month later he scored his fifth and sixth victories, making him the first American jet ace in history. He eventually scored 15 victories, giving him the title of "triple ace". Jabara was ranked as the second-highest-scoring U.S. ace of the Korean War. He received the [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Distinguished Service Cross]], [[Silver Star]], [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], [[Air Medal]], and the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|British Distinguished Flying Cross]] for his accomplishments in combat. Jabara next held a series of commands at various Air Force bases across the United States. He flew the [[Lockheed F-104 Starfighter]] and later the [[Convair B-58 Hustler]]. In 1966, while on leave from service in Vietnam, Colonel Jabara was traveling with his family in two cars to their new home when his daughter crashed the car she was driving and he was riding in, killing them both. They were buried together at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. In recognition of his contributions to military aviation, an airport outside of Wichita, Kansas was named in his honor. Each year the [[United States Air Force Academy]] alumni association bestows the [[Jabara Award]] upon an Academy graduate whose aerospace accomplishments demonstrate superior performance. ==Early life== Jabara was born in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]],{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International]]|title=First American Jet Ace Dies As Car Overturns in Florida|work=[[The New York Times]], ''18 November 1966 (Fee required)''|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0815FD3C5A137B93CAA8178AD95F428685F9|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=18 November 1966}} of [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] descent; his father, John, and mother came from [[Marjayoun]], a town in [[Southern Lebanon]].{{cite news|last=Dorr |first=Robert F. |title=History: Heroism across the ages |work=[[Navy Times]], ''2 September 2007'' |url=http://www.navytimes.com/community/opinion/airforce_60th_incredibleflights_070924w/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604IwkPb1?url=http://www.navytimes.com/community/opinion/airforce_60th_incredibleflights_070924w/ |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Jabara joined the [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]], eventually becoming an [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]].Boyne 2001, p. 331. At an early age, he was set on becoming a pilot, "I used to read articles about [[Eddie Rickenbacker|[Eddie] Rickenbacker]] and all these novels you read about air combat, and I guess from the sixth grade it was my ambition to be a fighter pilot."{{cite news|last=Allmon|first=William B|title=Captain James Jabara: Ace of the Korean War|work=Aviation History, ''March 1995''|publisher=HistoryNet.com|url=http://www.historynet.com/captain-james-jabara-ace-of-the-korean-war.htm|accessdate=10 July 2011}} He worked at his parents' grocery store{{cite news|last=Patrick |first=Bethanne Kelly |title=Col. James Jabara |work=[[Military.com]] |url=http://www.military.com/Content/MoreContent?file=ML_jabara_bkp |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6055TttrX?url=http://www.military.com/Content/MoreContent?file=ML_jabara_bkp |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and graduated from [[Wichita North High School]] in [[Wichita, Kansas]] in May 1942. Standing five feet, five inches (165 cm) tall,''Showdown: Air Combat F-86 Sabre vs. MIG-15'' [[Military Channel]] documentary Jabara was short for a potential fighter pilot (and was reportedly required to wear corrective eyewear), but this did not prevent him from immediately enlisting as an aviation cadet of the [[United States Army Air Corps]] at [[Fort Riley]], [[Kansas]].Fredriksen 1999, pp. 362–363. In an attempt to improve his eyesight for flying, he ate 20 carrots a day in the mistaken belief that this would improve his vision.{{cite news|last=Emery |first=Gary |title=Air Force pilot becomes first jet ace half century ago |work=dcmilitary.com, ''20 May 2001'' |url=http://ww2.dcmilitary.com/dcmilitary_archives/stories/052001/7451-1.shtml |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/605D0eQw6?url=http://ww2.dcmilitary.com/dcmilitary_archives/stories/052001/7451-1.shtml |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} After attending four flying schools in Texas, he received his pilot's wings and a commission as second lieutenant at [[Moore Field]], [[Texas]] in October 1943.{{cite news|last=Dorr |first=Robert F. |author2=Fred L. Borch |title=History in Blue: Jabara was first U.S. jet ace |work=[[Navy Times]], ''18 October 2006'' |url=http://www.navytimes.com/legacy/new/1-292925-2274298.php |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604qha278?url=http://www.navytimes.com/legacy/new/1-292925-2274298.php |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Jabara with his wife, Nina, had four children: James William (b. 1949), Carol Ann (b. 1950), Cathy (b. 1952), and Jeanne (b. 1957).{{cite news|last=''The New York Times'' staff|title=World's First Jet Ace Downs 2 MIG's within 10 Minutes|work=[[The New York Times]], ''21 May 1951 (Fee required)''|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B14FE3B5F147B93C3AB178ED85F458585F9|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=21 May 1951}}{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International|United Press]]|title=Jet Ace Welcomed Home by Eager Wife|work=[[The Deseret News]], ''29 May 1951''|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dZ1aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gk4DAAAAIBAJ&dq=james%20jabara%20nina&pg=5814%2C6518878|accessdate=3 September 2011}}{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International|United Press]]|title=Col. Jabara, First US Jet Ace, Killed|work=[[Chicago Tribune]], ''18 November 1966''|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/587186242.html?dids=587186242:587186242&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Nov+18%2C+1966&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=COL.+JABARA%2C+FIRST+U.+S.+JET+ACE%2C+KILLED&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|accessdate=3 September 2011|date=18 November 1966}} ==World War II== [[File:JamesJabaraCockpix1940s.jpg|thumb|right|Jabara sitting in a cockpit c. 1940s]] During [[World War II]], the [[Allies of World War II|Allied forces]] fought German aircraft across the [[European Theatre of World War II|European Theater]]. The Allies used several fighter aircraft, including the [[North American P-51 Mustang]]. Jabara was assigned to two tours of combat duty as a P-51 pilot across Europe. His first tour lasted from January to October 1944 with the [[363d Training Group|363d Fighter Group]] of the [[Ninth Air Force]]. On his first mission he was assigned to attacking German railroad targets in [[Belgium]]. In a March 1944 mission while Jabara was escorting bombers to Germany, a German pilot shot off his canopy. Although he faced below freezing temperatures at the high altitude, he was able to shoot down a German aircraft before returning to base. During one mission, while in formation, he and another P-51 pilot collided in midair. They both safely bailed out while the aircraft were destroyed.{{cite web|last=Randall|first=Peter|title=Database Search|publisher=Little Friends|url=http://www.littlefriends.co.uk/search.php?action=list_records&searchString=jabara&sort_order=ASC&order_by=Pilot&recs=100|accessdate=3 September 2011}} In another incident, while Jabara engaged a German aircraft, they collided in mid-air, and when both pilots safely floated to the ground, they met and shook hands. When Jabara's first tour ended, he returned to the United States as an instructor for other pilots. He returned to Europe again for his second tour from February to December 1945 with the [[355th Operations Group|355th Group]] of the [[Eighth Air Force]]. During his European combat (and known then as "the Ceegar Kid" for his penchant for smoking cigars), Jabara flew 108 combat missions. He was credited with the destruction of one and a half German aircraft in aerial combat (the half considered shared with another pilot)Wyllie 2005 (''WWII Victories''), p. 397.Dorr et al. 1995, p. 23. and four on the ground. He received a [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] with one [[Oak Leaf Cluster]] for his 1.5 victories as well as an [[Air Medal]] with 18 Oak Leaf Clusters. After World War II, Jabara considered leaving the military to attend college, but later decided to attend the Tactical Air School at [[Tyndall Air Force Base]], [[Florida]]. From 1947 to 1949 he was stationed on [[Okinawa]] with the [[53d Fighter Group]]. At Okinawa in 1948, Jabara flew his first jet aircraft, the Lockheed [[F-80 Shooting Star]]. Reflecting on the transition to jet aircraft, he said "It was entirely different. I was at 10,000 feet before I remembered to raise my landing gear. ...It was so quiet and fast. ...I guess that was probably the happiest moment of my life." Jabara returned to the United States and was assigned as a flight commander, now at the rank of captain, with the [[4th Fighter Wing|4th Fighter-Interceptor Wing]], flying the newly operational North American [[F-86 Sabre]] jet fighter at the [[New Castle Airport|New Castle County Airport]] in [[Delaware]]. ==Korean War== [[File:JamesJabaraCockpitStanding1950s.jpg|thumb|left|Jabara standing on his F-86 Sabre in April 1953]] Before the start of the [[Korean War]], the [[Korean Peninsula]] was split by an American-backed government at the south and a Soviet-backed opposing government at the north. Divided by the [[Division of Korea|38th Parallel]], both the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to maintain the division until a mutual decision was made about the future of the peninsula. On 25 June 1950, North Korean troops crossed the parallel and attacked several key South Korean targets. As the United States prepared military assistance with the South Koreans, the Soviet Union also helped the North Koreans by training pilots and providing [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]] aircraft. Jabara arrived in Korea on 13 December 1950 with the [[334th Fighter Squadron|334th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]] of the 4th Fighter-Interceptor Wing. The squadron was the first F-86 Sabre unit deployed to the [[Fifth Air Force]] to counter the threat by the Soviet MiG-15s. By 2 January 1951, he had flown five combat missions in F-86s and had damaged one MiG-15 Korean jet fighter in air combat.{{cite news|last=Parrott|first=Lindesay|title=Attack Gains Some Ground On Right Flank of 8th Army|work=[[The New York Times]], ''31 December 1950 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1950/12/31/archives/attack-gains-some-ground-on-right-flank-of-8th-army-un-troops.html|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=31 December 1950}} Jabara achieved his first confirmed victory on 3 April 1951 when 12 F-86 Sabres took on 12 MiG-15s in [[MiG Alley]], a region in northwestern [[North Korea]]. He was credited with another on 10 April, a third on 12 April,{{cite news|last=''The New York Times'' staff|title=Foe Seeks to Halt Attack|work=[[The New York Times]], ''13 April 1951 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1951/04/13/archives/8-migs-destroyed-in-great-air-fight-us-fliers-score-in-clashes-as.html|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=13 April 1951}} and a fourth on 22 April. Eager to get his fifth victory to be deemed a flying ace, Jabara voluntarily transferred to the [[335th Fighter Squadron|335th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]] when the 334th was rotated back to the United States. {{quote box|width=30em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote="This [air combat] is just business. It's what we're trained for—just like you might be trained for any business."|source=—James Jabara, reflecting on his combat victories{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Jet Ace Scouts Glamour|work=[[The New York Times]], ''13 April 1951 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1951/05/30/archives/jet-ace-scouts-glamour-says-air-fighting-is-just-business-in-modern.html|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=30 May 1951}}}} On 20 May, two flights of F-86 Sabres encountered multiple MiG-15s in MiG Alley, and through radio communications, two additional flights of F-86 Sabres joined the battle, including Jabara.{{cite journal|last=Farris |first=Phillip |title=Jet War |journal=[[Air Force Association|Air Force Magazine]] |url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/1990/June%201990/0690jetwar.aspx |volume=73 |number=6, June 1990 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604txzV3L?url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/1990/June%201990/0690jetwar.aspx |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In preparation for the oncoming battle, Jabara and the other F-86 Sabre pilots were ordered to jettison their auxiliary fuel tanks to improve their maneuverability. Jabara's right fuel tank failed to separate from his wing, and protocol required he return to base as the aircraft would be impeded by the extra weight and imbalance, and limit his potential to match off with a MiG. However, with his desire to become a jet ace, Jabara decided to continue to the air battle, where he was able to still handle his aircraft well enough to be credited with shooting down two MiG-15s with .50 caliber machine gun fire. The first was in a group of three MiGs and the other was the last in a six-plane group. Jabara was able to see the first aircraft explode from his gunfire, but he only saw his second victory go into a tailspin as he was avoiding being targeted by another MiG.Gurney 1958, p. 246. His fifth and sixth victories made Jabara the first American in history to use jet aircraft to become an ace.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=U.N. Blows Check Chinese Drive But Foe Pours in Troops|work=[[The New York Times]], ''21 May 1951 (Fee required)''|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0714FE3B5F147B93C3AB178ED85F458585F9|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=21 May 1951}} The Americans said the 20-minute air battle had included 36 F-86 Sabres against nearly 50 MiG-15s (Russian data shows 30 MiGs), and the American pilots recorded Jabara's two victories and another pilot's "probable". While returning to base, Jabara's F-86 Sabre was so low on fuel, he turned off the engine and glided towards the base before turning it on prior to landing. Data-matching with Soviet records made available since the end of the Cold War has since shown that only one MiG was lost in the combat, and that Jabara's jet-versus-jet tally was four at best. Nevertheless, American military forces claimed that Jabara was the first jet-versus-jet ace.http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_315.shtml Jabara later stated in an interview, "That was my bag for the day, and it made me feel pretty good to know that I was the first jet ace in the history of aerial warfare." The mission was his 63rd{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International|United Press]]|title=Jabara to Fight Again|work=[[The New York Times]], ''26 November 1952 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1952/11/26/archives/jabara-to-fight-again-jet-ace-receives-permission-to-complete-tour.html|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=26 November 1952}} Korean mission of an eventual 163;{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Jabara Misses Record|work=[[The New York Times]], ''18 July 1953''|date=}} he was awarded a [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Distinguished Service Cross]], the nation's second-highest decoration. {{double image|right|72d Fighter-Bomber Squadron - North American F-86F-35-NA Sabre - 52-5233.jpg|255|Mig 15 bis.jpg|210|The F-86 Sabre (left), flown by Jabara, was used to shoot down all of his 15 [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]] (right) air victories of the Korean War.}} Against his wishes, Jabara received a stateside leave for a publicity tour. The Jabara family grocery store in Wichita was thronged with people for days, and both he and his father John appeared on local and national radio and television. Wichita mounted one of its most-attended parades in the city's history. Jabara was even sent on a goodwill tour with his father through the Middle East, and gave a speech in his father's hometown of Marjayoun, Lebanon.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Jet Ace Pilot on Tour|work=[[The New York Times]], ''8 January 1952 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1952/01/08/archives/jet-ace-pilot-on-tour-major-jabara-takes-father-on-middle-east.html|accessdate=11 July 2011|date=8 January 1952}} Film [[newsreels]] included footage of his aircraft and other accolades included his own song ("That Jabara Bird") and a ritual rewarding of his Distinguished Service Cross at a Boston baseball game. Jabara returned to the United States in May 1951 for temporary assignment to Air Force Headquarters, Washington, D.C. Two months later he was transferred to the [[Air Training Command]] at [[Scott Air Force Base]], [[Illinois]]. Upon his request,{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=First Jet Ace Asks Return To Combat Duty in Korea|work=[[The New York Times]], ''13 November 1952 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1952/11/13/archives/first-jet-ace-asks-return-to-combat-duty-in-korea.html|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=13 November 1952}} he returned for another tour of duty overseas, arriving in Korea in January 1953.Thompson 2006, p. 37. By then a major, on his second tour, Jabara was credited with shooting down nine more MiGs for a total of 15 victories. On 16 May 1953 he recorded his seventh victory, and on 26 May he shot down two additional MiGs for a total of nine for the war. On 10 June, Jabara shot down two more MiGs. Eight days later his flight group encountered four MiGs, and he encountered mechanical problems that nearly caused his aircraft to crash into an elevated hill. After resolving his aircraft's issues, he returned to the battle and was able to shoot down an already damaged MiG. On 30 June, his first of two missions for the day resulted in one MiG victory. The second mission involved escorting F-86 Sabre fighter-bombers and he shot down a MiG before he came under heavy fire by other MiGs. In an attempt to evade their attack, he quickly accelerated but his engine flamed out. He maneuvered his aircraft for the ocean for a potential water rescue if he crashed, but he was able to restart the engine and return to base. Jabara recorded his final victory on 15 July. Two days later he flew his last two missions, and although he was eager to find more MiGs in an attempt to tie or surpass [[Joseph C. McConnell]]'s 16 air victories, he did not see any opposing aircraft.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Jet Ace Jabara Completes Last Korean Sortie|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ga1MAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HTEDAAAAIBAJ&dq=james%20jabara&pg=3096%2C6091851|work=[[Rome News-Tribune]], ''17 July 1953''|accessdate=10 July 2011}} His 15 victories gave him the title of "triple ace", and his Korean War victories were all against MiG-15s.Wyllie 2005 (''Aerial Victories''), p. 12. He received a [[Silver Star]], an Oak Leaf Cluster for his Distinguished Service Cross, as well as another Distinguished Flying Cross for his additional air victories. During the Korean War, Jabara was second in American air victories to McConnell, who recorded 16. The Soviet Union had [[List of Korean War flying aces|four other pilots]] who exceeded or tied Jabara's victories: [[Yevgeny Pepelyaev]] with 22.5, [[Nikolay V. Sutyagin]] with 22, and both [[Alexandr P. Smortzkow]] and [[Lev K. Schukin]] with 15.{{cite web|last=Bowers|first=Al|title=Fighter Pilot Aces|url=http://www.au.af.mil/au/awc/awcgate/aces/aces.htm|publisher=[[United States Air Force]], 15 May 1999|accessdate=3 September 2011}} ==After Korea== [[File:Convair B-58A Hustler in flight (SN 59-2442). Photo taken on June 29, 1967 061101-F-1234P-019.jpg|thumb|right|In one of Jabara's assignments after the Korean War, he piloted the [[Convair B-58 Hustler]], the first supersonic bomber]] Jabara returned to the United States in July 1953, and was assigned as commander of the [[4750th Air Defense Wing|4750th Training Squadron]] at [[Marine Corps Air Station Yuma|Yuma Air Force Base]] (later renamed [[MCAS Yuma|Vincent AFB]]), Arizona. By January 1957 Jabara was at [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida to join the 3243rd Test Group to test Lockheed F-104 Starfighters. He was first reassigned to Headquarters of the [[32d Air Division]] at [[Syracuse, New York]], then assumed command of the [[337th Flight Test Squadron|337th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]] at [[Westover Air Force Base]], [[Massachusetts]]. In 1958, Jabara flew combat missions over [[Taiwan]] in the F-104 Starfighter. From July 1960 to June 1961, he attended and graduated from the [[Air War College]] in [[Montgomery, Alabama]]. At [[Carswell Air Force Base]], Texas, Jabara piloted the first supersonic bomber, the [[Convair B-58 Hustler]] as part of the [[43d Airlift Wing|43d Bomb Wing]]. Jabara also helped train [[NATO]] pilots on the F-104 Starfighter in July 1964, when he was stationed at [[Luke Air Force Base]], Arizona and he wrote of the aircraft's significant technological improvement over the F-86 Sabre.{{cite journal|last=Jabara |first=James |title=A Fighter Pilot's Airplane |journal=[[Air Force Association|Air Force Magazine]] |url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/1960/August%201960/0860fighter.pdf |format=PDF |volume=43 |number=8, August 1960 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604w6tmDF?url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/1960/August%201960/0860fighter.pdf |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 1965, Jabara was given command of the [[31st Fighter Wing|31st Tactical Fighter Wing]] at [[Homestead Air Force Base]], Florida. By 1966 Jabara had risen to the rank of colonel—the youngest at that rank at the time, and he volunteered to fly combat missions for the Vietnam War. He flew his first mission in July 1966, joining a [[North American F-100 Super Sabre|F-100 Super Sabre]] flight group for a bombing run that damaged several buildings held by the [[Viet Cong]] in South Vietnam.{{cite news|title=Top Ace Enters His 3rd War|work=[[The Miami News]], ''20 July 1966''|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fcMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dusFAAAAIBAJ&dq=james-jabara&pg=3855%2C1278254|accessdate=28 July 2011}} He returned on leave to Homestead about a week after the mission. ==Death== [[File:JamesJabaraTombstoneMar2011.jpg|thumb|right|Jabara and his daughter's gravestone at Arlington National Cemetery]] While traveling to [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]], where his family would stay while he returned to combat in Vietnam, Jabara and his 16-year-old daughter Carol Anne died in a car accident in [[Delray Beach, Florida]], on 17 November 1966. The Jabara family were in two cars that day, on their way to a new home in South Carolina where his wife Nina and their children—James Jr., Carol Anne, Jeanne, and Cathy—would reside during Jabara's combat tour. Carol Anne was driving a [[Volkswagen]] with her father as a passenger in the back seat. She lost control of the car going through a construction zone, when she initially veered onto a grass median. She swerved back onto the highway but during the rapid turn, she lost control and the vehicle returned to the median where it rolled several times.{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International|UPI]]|title=James Jabara, World's First Jet Plane Ace, Killed|work=[[Observer-Reporter|The Washington Reporter]], ''18 November 1966''|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kOBdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2l4NAAAAIBAJ&dq=james-jabara&pg=908%2C2136735|accessdate=28 July 2011}}{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Jet Ace Dies in Crash on Florida Pike|work=[[The Vindicator|Youngstown Vindicator]], ''18 November 1966''|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wSFJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mIMMAAAAIBAJ&dq=james-jabara&pg=716%2C849296|accessdate=28 July 2011}} Jabara sustained head injuries and was pronounced dead on arrival at a Delray hospital, and Carol Anne died two days later. A memorial service was held for Jabara at Homestead Air Force Base with a [[Missing man formation|missing man formation fly-by]].{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Service Held for Jabara at Air Base|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]], ''22 November 1966''|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n_BRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YXQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5086,596992&dq=james+jabara&hl=en|accessdate=10 July 2011}} Jabara and his daughter were buried together in a single grave at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].[http://www.midwestaviation.com/about/jabara_history.cfm "Colonel James Jabara: American Hero."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516051148/http://www.midwestaviation.com/about/jabara_history.cfm |date=16 May 2008 }} ''Midwest Corporate Aviation.'' Retrieved: 10 July 2011.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Hero and Daughter Buried|work=[[The New York Times]], ''23 November 1966 (Fee required)''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1966/11/23/archives/hero-and-daughter-buried.html|accessdate=9 July 2011|date=23 November 1966}} His grandson, 2d Lt Nicholas Jabara, USAF, a 2001 graduate of the [[United States Air Force Academy]], was killed during pilot training in a [[Cessna T-37 Tweet|T-37]] accident at [[Laughlin AFB]], Texas on 31 January 2002.{{cite journal|last=Chapman |first=Suzann |title=Aerospace World |work=[[Air Force Association|Air Force Magazine]] |url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2002/July%202002/0702world.pdf |format=PDF |volume=85 |number=7, July 2002, |page=7 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604vWK0eE?url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2002/July%202002/0702world.pdf |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|last=de Leon|first=Virginia|title=Gonzaga Prep grad dies when jet crashes in Texas|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-pFXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=e_IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3496,933197&dq=nicholas+jabara+t-37+accident&hl=en|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]], ''2 February 2002''|accessdate=10 July 2011}} ==Legacy== An airport just northeast of [[Wichita, Kansas]], was named the [[Colonel James Jabara Airport]] in his honor.Price et al. 2010, p. 86. Each year since 1968, the United States Air Force Academy alumni association bestows the [[Jabara Award]] upon the Academy graduate whose accomplishments demonstrate superior performance in fields directly involved with aerospace vehicles.{{cite web|title=The Jabara Award for Airmanship|work=[[United States Air Force Academy]]|url=http://www1.usafa.org/Heritage/Jabara.aspx|accessdate=10 July 2011}}{{cite news|title=Awards |work=[[Air Force Times]], ''15 December 2003'' |url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/legacy/new/0-AIRPAPER-2445821.php |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604tTdRvz?url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/legacy/new/0-AIRPAPER-2445821.php |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The James Jabara Memorial Foundation was founded by a friend of Jabara, and the foundation constructed a statue of him at the Air Force Academy in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] in 2004.{{cite news|last=deGrandpr |first=Andrew |title=Friend keeps memory of America's first jet ace alive |work=[[Air Force Times]], ''18 October 2006'' |url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/legacy/new/1-292925-2274315.php |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604tOGoeR?url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/legacy/new/1-292925-2274315.php |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 1950, the [[Air Force Association]] (AFA) named him "Most Distinguished Aviator of the Year" and in 1957, was named by AFA as one of 25 U.S. men "who had done the most to promote aviation through the years". The [[Kansas Aviation Museum]] named him to the Kansas Aviation Hall of Fame in 2006.{{cite web|title=Kansas Hall of Fame Awards |work=[[Kansas Aviation Museum]] |url=http://www.kansasaviationmuseum.org/hall.php |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60BOGyQqN?url=http://www.kansasaviationmuseum.org/hall.php |archivedate=14 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Awards and decorations== During World War II, Colonel Jabara was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross with one Oak Leaf Cluster and the Air Medal with 23 Oak Leaf Clusters.{{cite web|last=Miner |first=Craig |title=James Jabara: Hero |work=[[Wings Over Kansas]] |url=http://www.wingsoverkansas.com/profiles/article.asp?id=61 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60BOct4Um?url=http://www.wingsoverkansas.com/profiles/article.asp?id=61 |archivedate=14 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} While in Korea he received the Distinguished Service Cross with one Oak Leaf Cluster and another Oak Leaf Cluster for his Distinguished Flying Cross. He was also awarded the Silver Star for two missions flown on 10 and 12 April 1951, where he shot down two MiGs while defending American bombers.{{cite news|title=Valor awards for James Jabara |work=[[Military Times|Military Times ''Hall of Valor'']] |url=http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=6959 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60BNZC2eq?url=http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=6959 |archivedate=14 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He received the Distinguished Service Cross for shooting down his fifth and sixth MiG victories on 20 May 1951. Another Silver Star was received in 1953 with an Oak Leaf Cluster. The United Kingdom awarded him the British Distinguished Flying Cross for his accomplishments in combat on 1 December 1955. {| align="center" |- |colspan="3" style="text-align:center;"|[[File:COMMAND PILOT WINGS.png|220px]] |- |colspan="3" style="text-align:center;"|{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=oak|ribbon=Distinguished Service Cross ribbon.svg|width=106}} |- |{{ribbon [https://books.google.com/books?id=CqLWUO1Ni_wC&lpg=PA353&dq=WWII%20Victories%20of%20the%20Army%20Air%20Force&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false ''WWII Victories of the Army Air Force.''] Raleigh, North Carolina: Lulu.com, 2005. {{ISBN|978-1-4116-4864-7}}. {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{webarchive |date=2012-08-01 |url=https://archive.is/20120801093054/http://www.af.mil/information/heritage/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006458 |title=United States Air Force Bio}} *[http://www.acepilots.com/korea_jabara.html AcePilots Bio] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121010145549/http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=1111 National Museum of the Air Force Fact Sheet] *{{Find a Grave|5862|accessdate=15 July 2008}} *[http://blog.buzzricksons.com/view-post/mig-madness ''Mig Madness''], Buzz Ricksons Blog {{DEFAULTSORT:Jabara, James}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1966 deaths]] [[Category:American Korean War flying aces]] [[Category:American people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:Aviators from Oklahoma]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:Eagle Scouts]] [[Category:People from Wichita, Kansas]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Service Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Air Medal]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in Florida]] [[Category:United States Air Force officers]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces pilots of World War II]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces officers]]
